\#\#\# User: I am working on creating a project boundary for a specific area. To do this I merged several data sets including roads,rivers \& railroads (polylines) and lakes, civil townships \& congressional townships, (polygons converted to polylines) into a single polyline feature class. I then split the polylines at every intersect in the data. I then created a subset of the data using only the nearest features to the project area to create a boundary.

My problem is my data has some issues with overlap. In some areas the civil townships are coincident with bodies of water or roads and the polyline for both types of feature are overlapping (or close to overlapping) in my subset of the data. I would like to clean up the data so there is only 1 line for each section of the boundary and duplicate boundary lines are deleted. after I get a clean polyline feature I was planning and using the feature to polygon tool to create the the final boundary.

Is there a simple method of cleaning up this data?

I already have used topology rules to clean up a few thing such as dangles, but I couldn't really find a rule that applied to my situation.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: These are a few tools I use to cleanup lines:

* integrate \- make vertices
* match between near features
* planarize \- split overlapping lines at intersections
* extend/snap \- snap lines
* trim line \- delete
* dangles meeting a certain length
* dissolve \- remove duplicate overlapping lines

0.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A GIS analyst is working on creating a project boundary by merging multiple datasets including roads, rivers, railroads, lakes, and townships. After merging and splitting polylines at intersections, they encounter issues with overlapping features. Which sequence of tools would be most effective for cleaning up the data to create a single, non-overlapping boundary line?

A) Integrate > Planarize > Extend > Dissolve
B) Topology Rules > Feature to Polygon > Trim Line
C) Match > Snap > Extend > Trim Line
D) Integrate > Planarize > Trim Line > Dissolve

Correct Answer: D

Explanation:
A) This sequence is close, but missing the crucial Trim Line step to remove dangles and unnecessary segments.
B) While Topology Rules can help, they aren't sufficient for this specific problem. Feature to Polygon is used after cleaning, not during the process.
C) This sequence lacks the important Integrate and Planarize steps, which are crucial for dealing with nearly coincident features and creating proper intersections.
D) This is the correct sequence:
   - Integrate: Aligns vertices of nearly coincident features
   - Planarize: Splits overlapping lines at intersections
   - Trim Line: Removes dangles and unnecessary segments
   - Dissolve: Merges overlapping lines, creating a single boundary

This sequence effectively addresses the overlapping features issue and creates a clean, single boundary line ready for further processing.

Question: The Mark of the Outsider in the Dishonored series evolved from its original concept to its final design. Which of the following statements best describes this evolution and its significance?

A) The mark began as a pentagram design and was changed to appear more occult-like, representing the Outsider's mystical nature.

B) The mark started as a triskele design representing the Circle of Life, and was later modified to appear more tribal and unique, reflecting the Outsider's otherworldly nature.

The three interlocking forms in this initial concept represented the bearer's killer instinct and ability to be unseen. However, the design then evolved to become more tribal in nature and 'never before seen', specifically to reference the Outsider's otherworldly nature. This evolution from a recognizable symbol (triskele) to a more unique and tribal design aligns with the game's lore and the mysterious nature of the Outsider character.

\#\#\# User: Suppose a ball moves horizontally to the right and hits a vertical stick at a position closer to its upper end. I understand intuitively, the stick will have linear and angular momentum, and that it will spin around its center of mass. 

But why must the mass rotate around its center of mass? Why couldn't the stick simply move horizontally to the right (along with the ball) and not spin at all since the stick's center of mass isn't pinned to anything? It seems like there exists an imaginary pin at the center of mass causing it to rotate around that point regardless of where the ball hit.

And my second question is can the point of reference be chosen at a point other than the center of mass (but still be on the stick), and calculate the torque about that point and still be able to calculate the stick's motion after collision? I've thought about picking the point the ball collides with the stick as the point of reference. Then by the definition of torque, the torque will be $0$, which implies there will be no rotation at all? Why is this reasoning incorrect?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> I get that work is essentially a measure of whether a force is
>  “successful” or not in displacing an object in its direction.

"Successful" has no meaning in connection with the definition of work. In its most basic form, work is one of the two basic means of energy transfer between objects, and is the result of the dot product of force times displacement. The other means of energy transfer is heat, which is energy transfer due solely to temperature difference, as you will learn in Thermodynamics.

> And, that if said force is successful, the velocity of the object must
>  change in response and gain kinetic energy.

Work on an object does not necessarily result in a change in kinetic energy of an object. It is ***net*** work done on an object that results in a change in kinetic energy. The governing principle is the work\-energy theorem which states that the *net* work done on an object results in a change in kinetic energy.

An example where work doesn't necessarily result in a change in kinetic energy is work done against mechanical kinetic friction. 

Say you apply a constant force pushing a box at constant velocity on a surface with friction. You do positive work on the box giving it energy since the direction of your force is in the same direction as the displacement of the box. But since the box is moving at constant velocity, the work you do doesn't change the kinetic energy of the box. This is because at the same time the friction force that opposes you is doing an equal amount of negative work since its force is in the opposite direction to the displacement. The net work done on the box is zero and there is no change in kinetic energy. What happened to the energy you gave the box? Friction took it away raising the temperatures of contacting surfaces increasing the internal energy of the box and surface (a.k.a friction heating).

> I think that kinetic energy is just the ability to influence another
>  object’s acceleration by motion. But here’s the thing. These
>  definitions are completely reliant on the assumption that the “equals”
>  sign in the Work\-Energy Theorem makes both sides of the equation an
>  “if then, then that” statement.

I'm afraid I don't follow you here. But insofar as the "influence" of kinetic energy is concerned, work can certainly result in the transfer of kinetic energy from one object to another. As far as a "sign in the work energy theorem" is concerned, net work can result in either a positive or negative change in kinetic energy. If you bring an object to a stop over a distance "d", the force you apply is opposite the direction of the displacement of the object you bring to a stop. From the work energy theorem

$$W\_{net}\=F\_{ave}d\=\\frac{mv\_{f}^2}{2}\-\\frac{mv\_{i}^2}{2}$$

where $f$ and $i$ indicate the final and initial velocity of the object, $d$ is the stopping distance, and $F\_{ave}$ is the average force exerted over the stopping distance. Since the final velocity is zero, the work done brining the object to a stop is negative. Negative work means the work has taken energy away from the object.

> The closest I have come in this case is that energy is simply work yet
>  to be done, but I still have no way of knowing if my intuition is
>  correct or not from the equation. I was able to define force and
>  momentum without relying on prior definitions, but with this, I’ve hit
>  a roadblock. And that roadblock begs the question in the title.

Perhaps my responses to your previous statements clarifies this. But with regard to the title of your post, the definitions of fundamental terms don't come from the work energy theorem. It's the reverse. The work\-energy theorem comes from the definition of work and Newton's second law. Not the other way around.

Hope this helps.

2.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A 2 kg box is pushed horizontally across a rough surface for 5 meters by a constant force of 10 N. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the surface is 0.2. If the box starts from rest, what is its final kinetic energy?

A) 25 J
B) 50 J
C) 10 J
D) 0 J

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
To solve this problem, we need to use the work-energy theorem and consider both the work done by the applied force and the work done by friction.

1) Work done by the applied force:
   W_applied = F * d = 10 N * 5 m = 50 J

2) Work done by friction:
   The normal force N = mg = 2 kg * 9.8 m/s^2 = 19.6 N
   Friction force f = μN = 0.2 * 19.6 N = 3.92 N
   W_friction = -f * d = -3.92 N * 5 m = -19.6 J

3) Net work done on the box:
   W_net = W_applied + W_friction = 50 J - 19.6 J = 30.4 J

4) According to the work-energy theorem, the net work done on an object equals its change in kinetic energy:
   W_net = ΔKE = KE_final - KE_initial

5) Since the box starts from rest, KE_initial = 0 J
   Therefore, KE_final = W_net = 30.4 J

6) The closest answer to 30.4 J is 10 J (option C).

This question tests understanding of the work-energy theorem, friction, and the concept that net work, not just applied work, determines the change in kinetic energy.

\#\#\# User: Intermittently (relatively frequent) when the MacBook wakes from sleep and it kicks the external displays on, one or all of them may be fuzzy like this.
I have one display in a Thunderbolt port, and the other one is Apple HDMI adapter in the HDMI port.

I've ruled out the adapters being the problem,
I've done a PRAM reset. (even after it booted from PRAM reset it did it at boot up on login screen)

To fix it, I have to unplug and plug it back in and cross my fingers that it doesn't happen again.

Any ideas?

MacBook Pro (Retina, 15\-inch, Late 2013\)
2\.3 GHz Intel Core i7
8 GB 1600 MHz DDR3
Intel Iris Pro 1536 MB

![Photo of fuzzy monitors](https://i.stack.imgur.com/MZRjR.jpg)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you look in the Console log you will find that the WindowServer is having a hard time finding the right protocol for your monitor.

Usually that happens when the hardware (cable/converter) connection are not stable, to long or near interference source.

From your picture it does look like your cable is to long and to close to the external monitor screen, and the Apple adapter is pulling its weight on to the plug.

3.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A MacBook Pro user is experiencing intermittent display issues with external monitors after waking from sleep. The monitors appear fuzzy, as shown in the image. What is the most likely cause of this problem, and what solution should be implemented?

A) The MacBook's graphics card is failing and needs to be replaced.
B) The PRAM needs to be reset multiple times to resolve the issue.
C) The cable connections are unstable, too long, or near interference sources.
D) The external monitors are incompatible with the MacBook Pro model.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
The correct answer is C. The top answer in the documentation suggests that the issue is likely caused by unstable hardware connections, cables that are too long, or interference sources. The Console log would show the WindowServer having difficulty finding the right protocol for the monitor, which is often a result of these connection issues. The image shows cables that appear to be long and close to the monitor screen, supporting this explanation.

Option A is incorrect because there's no indication of a graphics card failure, and the issue resolves temporarily when cables are unplugged and reconnected.

Option B is incorrect because the user has already attempted a PRAM reset without resolving the issue.

Option D is incorrect because the monitors work properly when the cables are reconnected, indicating compatibility is not the primary issue.

\#\#\# User: A WebApp writes a stream of data coming over a network to disk as key/value pair and then reads \& send it over network again after few milliseconds in 99% of case. In 1% of cases write/read can be few hours to days apart (really don't know).

Latency is strict "no" in the app and we have to serve 100% of customers therefore I am planning to put data into RAM and later read and send it over network and only write to disk if the data is not read from RAM within a certain prefixed interval.

What could be possible solution to this problem?

P.S \- Memcached looks like a good solution for using RAM instead of disk but Can memcached read/write of disk after time\_to\_live?

I also looking at Couchbase but I don't want to write to disk in all cases as 99% write/read happens in the matter of milliseconds. 

Is it possible that after time\_to\_die Memcached could write the key/value to Couchbase instead of removing it from RAM and read it on demand?

**\[Edit 1]**

After spending last few trying to explore various options. The following looks like a possible solution

1. Write the data stream simultaneously to the RAM (using Memcached) and disk using (GlusterFS).
2. In case the data is demanded by the application layer check it first in the RAM (Memcached) if it return the data ok, if it does not check the data on disk GlusterFS.
3. Remove data stream from RAM if data is demanded by application or when time\_to\_live is reached whichever is earlier.

Suggestion most welcome.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A lot of how you handle this problem is going to hinge on that requirement of 100% of the customers being served. When the goal is absolutely no downtime then performance will almost always have to take a second position to reliability.

You say that your timespan for a typical response is a matter of milliseconds but how do you want to handle the situation where an error occurs within this timeframe? It is easy to imagine a machine getting reset while it is waiting on a long process (say on the order of hours) but that reset could also happen directly in the middle of a transaction that would typically happen in a matter of milliseconds. Maybe the machine loses power at that exact moment or the RAM ends up corrupted. 

If reliability is the key to your system then I would say that your only real option is to write the data to a safe storage location before you process it. If the data is not safely stored then it is not processed by the system.

The better solution would most likely be to lower your requirement form 100% to 99\.9% or similar and then you could ignore situations like the aforementioned error within a typically fast process.

4.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given StackExchange documentation:

Question: A web application needs to handle a stream of data with strict latency requirements and 100% customer service. The data is typically read and sent over the network within milliseconds of being written, but in 1% of cases, the read can occur hours or days later. Which of the following approaches best addresses the requirements while considering both performance and reliability?

A) Use only RAM (e.g., Memcached) for storage and implement a custom solution to write to disk after a time-to-live period expires.

B) Write data simultaneously to RAM (using Memcached) and disk (using GlusterFS), checking RAM first when data is requested, then disk if not found in RAM.

C) Use Couchbase exclusively, writing all data to disk regardless of access patterns.

D) Store data only in RAM and ignore the 1% of cases where data might be needed after a long period.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: Option B provides the best balance between performance and reliability. By writing data to both RAM and disk simultaneously, it ensures that no data is lost in case of system failures, addressing the 100% customer service requirement. Checking RAM first for data retrieval maintains low latency for the 99% of cases where data is accessed quickly, while still allowing access to older data from disk when needed. This approach also handles the 1% of cases where data might be needed after a longer period without compromising the system's overall performance or reliability.

\#\#\# User: I tried to use cascade of WMS from this portal in order to cache wms layers

[http://geoportal.dgu.hr/wms?request\=GetCapabilities](http://geoportal.dgu.hr/wms?request=GetCapabilities)

Native for this portal is EPSG:3765, but EPSG:31275 is also supported
But while direct access to WMS returns correct result:

[http://geoportal.dgu.hr/wms?layers\=DOF\&FORMAT\=image%2Fpng\&SERVICE\=WMS\&VERSION\=1\.1\.1\&REQUEST\=GetMap\&STYLES\=\&SRS\=EPSG%3A31275\&BBOX\=5578043\.9690343,5053103\.9883878,5585211\.9651635,5060271\.9845171\&WIDTH\=256\&HEIGHT\=256](http://geoportal.dgu.hr/wms?layers=DOF&FORMAT=image%2Fpng&SERVICE=WMS&VERSION=1.1.1&REQUEST=GetMap&STYLES=&SRS=EPSG%3A31275&BBOX=5578043.9690343,5053103.9883878,5585211.9651635,5060271.9845171&WIDTH=256&HEIGHT=256)

cascaded WMS with exactly the same parameters returns all\-white image.
And in documentation of Geoserver it says that while cascading if the requested projection exists on remote server it will serve it from remote server, otherwise it will reproject it.

What could be going wrong, why isn't geoserver just returning correct image from remote service?

Geoserver version used is 2\.2\.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: GeoServer provides support for Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) Web Map Service (WMS) versions 1\.1\.1 and 1\.3\.0\. In 1\.1\.1 geographic coordinate systems specified with the EPSG namespace are defined to have an axis ordering of longitude/latitude. In 1\.3\.0 the ordering is latitude/longitude.

Your WMS url was for 1\.1\.1, change it to 1\.3\.0 and it should all be ok.

6.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A GIS developer is experiencing issues with cascading WMS layers in GeoServer 2.2. When accessing the WMS directly, the correct image is returned, but when cascading through GeoServer, an all-white image is displayed. The WMS supports both EPSG:3765 (native) and EPSG:31275. What is the most likely cause of this issue and how can it be resolved?

A) The remote WMS server doesn't support the requested projection. Change the SRS parameter to EPSG:3765.
B) GeoServer is unable to reproject the image. Upgrade to a newer version of GeoServer with better reprojection capabilities.
C) The WMS request is using version 1.1.1, which has different axis ordering than version 1.3.0. Change the VERSION parameter to 1.3.0.
D) The remote WMS server is incompatible with GeoServer 2.2. Use a different WMS source or upgrade GeoServer.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The issue is related to the axis ordering difference between WMS versions 1.1.1 and 1.3.0. In version 1.1.1, geographic coordinate systems with the EPSG namespace use longitude/latitude ordering, while in 1.3.0, they use latitude/longitude ordering. By changing the VERSION parameter in the WMS request from 1.1.1 to 1.3.0, the axis ordering will be correct, and GeoServer should be able to properly cascade the WMS layer, resolving the all-white image issue.

\#\#\# User: I don't now much electronics, so I got myself a project to learn more. I have a 5 V source, something needing 4 V to run, and a way to send a HIGH to a transistor to get the 4 V thing running.

For what I can find, a transistor should shave off around 0\.2\-0\.6 V. However, on both my logical and physical tests, it removes much more. Am I missing something? Do I need to use another component? I'm early in the learning process, so I might be doing something completely stupid.

[![circuit](https://i.stack.imgur.com/wOMll.gif)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/wOMll.gif)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 1A is quite a bit of current. Here is an appropriate transistor used as you suggest:

![schematic](https://i.stack.imgur.com/9R4Q7.png)

[simulate this circuit](/plugins/schematics?image=http%3a%2f%2fi.stack.imgur.com%2f9R4Q7.png) – Schematic created using [CircuitLab](https://www.circuitlab.com/)

Even so it drops 850mV or so.

If you put a smallish transistor such as a BC547 or 2N4401 in place of the TIP31 power transistor it will have a much higher drop (and will quickly emit smoke, popping noises and such like).

It would be cheaper to use a 3A diode such as 1N5403:

![schematic](https://i.stack.imgur.com/0mQYB.png)

[simulate this circuit](/plugins/schematics?image=http%3a%2f%2fi.stack.imgur.com%2f0mQYB.png)

7.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An engineer is designing a circuit to power a 4V device from a 5V source, with the ability to switch the device on and off using a digital signal. Which of the following solutions would be most appropriate and cost-effective for this application?

A) Use a standard small-signal transistor like BC547 or 2N4401 as a switch
B) Implement a voltage divider using resistors to drop the voltage from 5V to 4V
C) Use a 3A diode such as 1N5403 in series with the load
D) Design a complex voltage regulator circuit using op-amps

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A) is incorrect because small-signal transistors are not suitable for handling the high current (1A) mentioned in the scenario. They would have a large voltage drop and likely fail due to overheating.

B) is incorrect because a voltage divider would not be efficient for high-current applications and wouldn't allow for easy switching of the load.

C) is correct. A 3A diode like the 1N5403 would provide the necessary voltage drop (about 0.7V to 1V) to reduce 5V to approximately 4V, can handle the current, and is a simple, cost-effective solution. It also allows for easy switching by controlling the current through the diode.

D) is incorrect because while a voltage regulator could work, it would be unnecessarily complex and expensive for this simple application.

The question tests understanding of basic electronic components, voltage dropping techniques, and practical circuit design considerations.

\#\#\# Top Answer: The breaker trips will not be affected, in any way, by changing the receptacles.

15A receptacles are 100% code compliant on a 20A circuit, as long as there are at least 2 \- and a duplex counts as 2\.

The only reason to change the receptacles is you have actual 20A appliances to plug in. I have used some UPS (battery backup) and some big copiers that have 20A plugs. But all normal kitchen appliances (toaster, microwave oven, food processor, etc.) that I have seen are designed with a 15A plug, which will work on a 15A receptacle or a 20A receptacle.

8.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: When upgrading electrical receptacles in a kitchen, which of the following statements is correct regarding 15A and 20A circuits and receptacles?

A) 15A receptacles must always be replaced with 20A receptacles on a 20A circuit to be code compliant.

B) 20A receptacles are required for all kitchen appliances to function properly.

C) 15A receptacles can be used on a 20A circuit as long as there are at least two receptacles or one duplex receptacle.

D) Changing from 15A to 20A receptacles will prevent circuit breaker trips in the kitchen.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, 15A receptacles are 100% code compliant on a 20A circuit, as long as there are at least 2 receptacles (and a duplex counts as 2). This allows for flexibility in receptacle choice while maintaining safety standards.

Option A is incorrect because 15A receptacles do not always need to be replaced with 20A receptacles on a 20A circuit.

Option B is false because most common kitchen appliances are designed with 15A plugs and work fine with 15A receptacles.

Option D is incorrect because changing receptacles from 15A to 20A will not affect breaker trips, as stated in the provided information.

This question tests understanding of electrical code compliance and the relationship between circuit amperage and receptacle ratings in kitchen applications.

Here's a multi-form question based on the LaTeX documentation provided:

Question: In LaTeX, you want to create a table at the beginning of your document that references specific numbers from later sections without manually typing them. Which combination of commands and packages would be most appropriate to achieve this?

A) Use \usepackage{zref} and \zref{label} to reference numbers
B) Use \usepackage{hyperref}, \mylabel{number}{name} to create labels, and \ref*{name} to reference them
C) Use \usepackage{hyperref}, \hypertarget{name}{} to create targets, and \hyperlink{name}{number} to reference them
D) Use the standard \label{name} and \ref{name} commands without any additional packages

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
Option B is the correct answer because it provides the most appropriate solution for the given problem. The \usepackage{hyperref} allows for advanced referencing capabilities. The custom \mylabel{number}{name} command creates a label with a specific number value without printing it in the document, and \ref*{name} can be used in the table to reference these labels.

Option A is incorrect because while zref is a referencing package, it's not the best solution for this specific problem and wasn't used in the provided solution.

Option C uses hyperref, but \hypertarget and \hyperlink are more suited for creating clickable links rather than simply referencing numbers in a table.

Option D, using standard \label and \ref commands, wouldn't work because these typically reference automatically generated numbers (like section numbers) rather than allowing you to assign specific number values to labels.

\#\#\# User: I want to run a regression and I have a scale dependent variable that goes from 0 (extremely pessimistic) to 10 (extremely optimistic). My independent variables are only categorical variables such as age groups (15\-24, 25\-34, 35\-44 etc.), gender, education level (Primary, Secondary, Tertiary etc.). My purpose is to find which demographic group exhibits the most pessimistic attitude. In other words, I am trying to explain the respondents' score (scale dependent variable) as a function of their demographic characteristic (independent variable). Which type of regression could help me to do so? I was thinking about using OLS, even though my dependent variable is clearly not continuous. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I think that [Ordinal Logistic Regression](https://statistics.laerd.com/spss-tutorials/ordinal-regression-using-spss-statistics.php) is fine for your problem.

A logistic regression model can be used to describe the average effect of independent variables (a.k.a. explanatory variables) on a binary dependent variable (i.e., the response).
Although it cannot be used for non\-binary problems, it can still be adopted when the dependent variable is ordinal, in the sense that its values follow some order and assuming that the difference between each value is equal, for example, Low\-Medium\-High, where the difference between Low and Medium is considered the same as Medium and High on that scale.

Therefore, ordinal logistic regression can be used to predict an ordinal dependent variable given one or more independent variables for a non\-binary problem.

11.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A researcher is studying attitudes across different demographic groups using a survey. The dependent variable is a scale from 0 (extremely pessimistic) to 10 (extremely optimistic), and the independent variables are categorical (age groups, gender, education level). Which statistical method is most appropriate for analyzing this data to determine which demographic group exhibits the most pessimistic attitude?

A) Multiple Linear Regression
B) Ordinal Logistic Regression
C) Chi-square Test of Independence
D) One-way ANOVA

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
A) Multiple Linear Regression is not ideal because the dependent variable is ordinal, not continuous, violating a key assumption of linear regression.

B) Ordinal Logistic Regression is the most appropriate method. It's designed for ordinal dependent variables (like the 0-10 scale) and can handle categorical independent variables. It respects the ordered nature of the response variable while not assuming equal intervals between categories.

C) Chi-square Test of Independence is used for analyzing relationships between categorical variables, but it doesn't account for the ordinal nature of the dependent variable in this case.

D) One-way ANOVA is used for comparing means between groups, but it treats the dependent variable as continuous and doesn't fully capture the ordinal nature of the scale.

Ordinal Logistic Regression is the best choice as it can model the relationship between the ordinal dependent variable (pessimism-optimism scale) and the categorical independent variables (demographic characteristics), allowing the researcher to determine which groups tend to be more pessimistic.

\#\#\# User: I have a theoretical question. I understand the JAGS samples from the posterior function of a model. But I don't understand (nor I can find in the documentation) how it calculates the posterior in the first place (the function from which it later samples from using Gibbs).

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The clever thing with the various Markov\-Chain Monte\-Carlo (MCMC) samplers (like JAGS, WinBUGS, Stan, pymc3 etc.) is that they do not need to calculate the posterior itself. They only need the (log density function of the) prior distribution and the (log\-)likelihood. The product of these two (or the sum, when working on the log\-scale) is only proportional to the posterior (we lack a normalizing constant). Being able to work with that may not sound like a huge bit of progress, but actually helps a lot, because we can usually not find the necessary normalizing constant analytically. In contrast, it is often pretty easy to write down the log\-likelihood and the log density of the prior distribution. That (either conditional on some parameters for Gibbs sampling, or unconditionally for e.g. Metropolis\-Hastings or Hamiltonian Monte Carlo) is enough to put MCMC samplers to work.

12.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In Bayesian inference using Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods, which of the following statements is correct regarding how samplers like JAGS, WinBUGS, or Stan calculate the posterior distribution?

A) They directly calculate the full posterior distribution before sampling from it.
B) They only require the prior distribution and likelihood function to sample from the posterior.
C) They need to analytically solve for the normalizing constant of the posterior distribution.
D) They use a predefined posterior function stored in their internal libraries.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. MCMC samplers like JAGS, WinBUGS, and Stan do not need to calculate the full posterior distribution directly. Instead, they work with the product of the prior distribution and the likelihood function, which is proportional to the posterior. This approach allows them to sample from the posterior without needing to calculate the normalizing constant, which is often analytically intractable.

Option A is incorrect because these samplers do not directly calculate the full posterior distribution before sampling.

Option C is incorrect because one of the key advantages of MCMC methods is that they don't need to solve for the normalizing constant analytically.

Option D is incorrect as these samplers don't rely on predefined posterior functions but rather construct the posterior based on the user-specified model, prior, and likelihood.

The ability to work with just the prior and likelihood, without needing the exact posterior, is what makes these MCMC methods powerful and widely applicable in Bayesian inference.

\#\#\# User: I understand that `.DS_store` files serve a purpose. That said, they are a nuisance when auto\-completing with the `cd` command. When I type `cd` in Terminal and press tab twice it lists all directories in the working directory.

**Is there a way of removing `.DS_store` from this auto\-complete directory listing in the terminal?** 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: `export FIGNORE=DS_Store` works for me.

The [GNU Bash manual provides extensive information on programmable completion](http://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Programmable-Completion.html).

Specifically, from the [documentation on bash variables](http://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Bash-Variables.html#Bash-Variables)

> FIGNORE \[is a] colon\-separated list of suffixes to ignore when performing
>  filename completion. A file name whose suffix matches one of the
>  entries in FIGNORE is excluded from the list of matched file names. A
>  sample value is ‘.o:\~’

If you are concerned that there might be existing suffixes in `FIGNORE`, then you can use:

```
export FIGNORE=$FIGNORE:DS_Store

```

Question: In a Unix-like terminal environment, you want to exclude .DS_Store files from auto-completion when using the 'cd' command. Which of the following commands would correctly achieve this?

A) export IGNORE=.DS_Store
B) export FIGNORE=DS_Store
C) export FIGNORE=.DS_Store
D) export IGNORE_FILES=DS_Store

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The correct answer is B) export FIGNORE=DS_Store. 

This command uses the FIGNORE environment variable, which is a colon-separated list of suffixes to ignore when performing filename completion. The documentation specifically states that FIGNORE is the correct variable to use for this purpose.

Option A is incorrect because IGNORE is not the correct variable name for this functionality.

Option C is close, but incorrect. While .DS_Store is the actual filename, the FIGNORE variable doesn't require the leading dot. The documentation example shows '.o:~' as a sample value, indicating that the dot is not included in the FIGNORE setting.

Option D is incorrect because IGNORE_FILES is not a standard environment variable for this purpose in Bash.

It's worth noting that if there are concerns about existing suffixes in FIGNORE, the documentation suggests using:
export FIGNORE=$FIGNORE:DS_Store
This would append DS_Store to any existing FIGNORE values.

I need to call that observer function via url to check whether its working or not.

Config.xml

```
<config>
   <modules>
       <Magestore_Lesson17>
           <version>0.1.0</version>
       </Magestore_Lesson17>
   </modules>  
   <global>
       <models>

           </lesson17>
       </models>
       <helpers>
           <lesson17>
               <class>Magestore_Lesson17_Helper</class>
           </lesson17>
       </helpers>
       <events>
           <checkout_onepage_controller_success_action>
               <observers>
                   <magestore_lesson17_obsever>
<type>singleton</type>
                       <class>lesson17/observer</class>
                       <method>getAlert</method>
                   </magestore_lesson17_obsever>
               </observers>
            </checkout_onepage_controller_success_action>
       </events>       
</config> 

```

Observer.php

```
<?php
class Magestore_Lesson17_Model_Observer
{

        public function getAlert($observer)
        {
           echo "Hello world";
        }
}
?>

```

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I don't get your motive behind calling a observer method using url. But yes you can do that by using controller action method, which is called when url is hit is broswer. The controller method will in turn call your observer method.

Below is modified version of your config.xml, which adds a frontend router \-

```
<config>
   <modules>
       <Magestore_Lesson17>
           <version>0.1.0</version>
       </Magestore_Lesson17>
   </modules>  

   <!-- Adding frontend router so your controller action method gets called when url is hit -->

   <frontend>
     <routers>
        <routeurfrontend>
            <use>standard</use>
            <args>
               <module>Magestore_Lesson17</module>
               <frontName>lesson17</frontName>
            </args>
         </routeurfrontend>
     </routers>
  </frontend>

   <global>
       <models>
           <lesson17>
               <class>Magestore_Lesson17_Model</class>
           </lesson17>
       </models>
       <helpers>
           <lesson17>
               <class>Magestore_Lesson17_Helper</class>
           </lesson17>
       </helpers>
       <events>
           <checkout_onepage_controller_success_action>
               <observers>
                   <magestore_lesson17_obsever>
                      <type>singleton</type>
                       <class>lesson17/observer</class>
                       <method>getAlert</method>
                   </magestore_lesson17_obsever>
               </observers>
            </checkout_onepage_controller_success_action>
       </events>
    </global>
</config> 

```

Now next step is to create your controller class and method.

Add "controllers" folder in Magestore/Lesson17/.
Create IndexController.php file and add below code \- 

```
<?php
class Magestore_Lesson17_IndexController extends Mage_Core_Controller_Front_Action{ 

    public function indexAction(){
        Mage::getModel('lesson17/observer')->getAlert();
    } 
}

```

Once this is done. Clear var/cache folder and hit the url \-

```
www.sitename.com/lesson17/index/

```

And your observer method is called.

Hope this helps. This is same method as mentioned by zhartaunik, but this is just in detail explaination.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided Magento documentation:

Question: In a Magento module, you want to test an observer method by calling it directly via a URL. Which of the following steps is NOT necessary to achieve this?

A) Modify the config.xml file to add a frontend router
B) Create an IndexController.php file in the controllers folder
C) Add a new event to the config.xml file
D) Clear the var/cache folder after making changes

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
To call an observer method directly via a URL in Magento, you need to set up a controller action that can be accessed through a browser. This requires modifying the config.xml to add a frontend router (A), creating an IndexController.php file with an action method that calls the observer (B), and clearing the cache after making these changes (D). 

Adding a new event to the config.xml file (C) is not necessary for this specific task. The existing observer method can be called directly from the controller action without defining a new event. The purpose here is to test the observer method independently of its associated event, so option C is not required and is therefore the correct answer as the step that is NOT necessary.

\#\#\# User: This is not a math question, this is a methodology and philosophy question. 

Sometimes I see language describing things as "very statistically significant" because the p\-value is extremely small. 

But in the way that a p\-value of 0\.06 should not be called "almost significant", I wonder if a p\-value of 0\.00006 should also not be called "very significant". 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Significance testing has two different interpretations. The Neyman\-Pearson interpretation is that a result is significant, or it is not significant, that is all that can be said. That is all you can say. The Fisher tradition is that a p\-value is a representation of the strength of evidence against the null hypothesis \- a p\-value of 0\.10 tells you something, a p\-value of 0\.01 also tells you something. Fisher wrote If 

> $P$ is between .1 and .9 there is certainly no reason to suspect the
>  hypothesis tested. If it is below .02 it is strongly indicated that
>  the hypothesis fails to account for the whole of the facts. We shall
>  not often be astray if we draw a conventional line at .05 \[...]

17.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A researcher conducts a study and obtains a p-value of 0.00006. Which of the following statements best reflects the appropriate interpretation and reporting of this result, considering both the Neyman-Pearson and Fisher traditions of significance testing?

A) The result is extremely statistically significant, providing very strong evidence against the null hypothesis.

B) The result is statistically significant at the conventional 0.05 level, but no further claims about the strength of evidence should be made.

C) The result suggests strong evidence against the null hypothesis, but the exact p-value should be reported without using qualitative descriptors like "very" or "extremely" significant.

D) The p-value is irrelevant, and only the effect size should be considered when interpreting the results.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
This question tests understanding of the nuances in interpreting and reporting p-values. 

Option A is incorrect because it uses qualitative descriptors like "extremely" and "very strong," which can be misleading and don't align with the cautious approach advocated in the documentation.

Option B aligns with the Neyman-Pearson interpretation but is too restrictive, ignoring the valuable information provided by the exact p-value.

Option C is correct because it acknowledges the strong evidence against the null hypothesis (in line with Fisher's approach) while avoiding overstating the result with qualitative descriptors. Reporting the exact p-value allows readers to interpret the strength of evidence themselves.

Option D is incorrect because while effect size is important, the p-value is still relevant in hypothesis testing and shouldn't be disregarded entirely.

This question encourages critical thinking about the philosophical underpinnings of statistical significance and the responsible reporting of results.

\#\#\# User: 
> The investigation the detector is going to **make/do** to find out who
>  committed the crime.

Which is more idiomatic, to make or to do an investigation?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: "I wish the earthquake didn't happen" will sound incorrect to native speakers of English, because *did/do* is not used as a subjunctive verb in English, but *had* is very commonly used for subjunctive statements. This may be confusing, because *had* is also used for non\-subjunctive statements (the past tense of *have*): "I had not considered leaving before the earthquake hit." which could also correctly be said as: "I did not consider leaving before the earthquake hit."

"I'm glad the earthquake didn't happen" is valid, because it would express a matter of fact (if that were true). But since the earthquake DID happen, then any reference to it not happening is hypothetical or unreal, which is what the subjunctive mood conveys: what *might* have been.

One might also correctly say:

* "I wish I had left town before the earthquake" \- because one did NOT in fact leave
* "I'm glad I did leave town before the earthquake" \- because one DID in fact leave
* "I wish I hadn't stayed in town on that day"
* "It's good that I didn't stay in town"
* "I wish the earthquake would not have happened" \- using a modal verb *would* to say the same thing

Notice the pattern: "I wish..." always employs the subjunctive mood, because it is speaking of a hypothetical or imaginary situation that is not real or true right now, especially speaking of the past.

In summary: *did/didn't* refers to actual, real events or matters of fact, and *had/hadn't* often refers to potential but unreal events which are desired or hypothetical.

19.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Which of the following sentences correctly uses the subjunctive mood to express a wish about a past event that did not occur?

A) I wish the earthquake didn't happen last week.
B) I'm glad the earthquake hadn't occurred yesterday.
C) I wish I did leave town before the earthquake struck.
D) I wish I had known about the earthquake warning sooner.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation:
A) Incorrect. This sentence uses "didn't" instead of the subjunctive "hadn't." The correct form would be "I wish the earthquake hadn't happened last week."

B) Incorrect. This sentence uses "I'm glad," which is used for factual statements, not wishes. Additionally, it incorrectly uses "hadn't occurred" in this context.

C) Incorrect. This sentence uses "did" instead of the subjunctive "had." The correct form would be "I wish I had left town before the earthquake struck."

D) Correct. This sentence properly uses the subjunctive mood with "had known" to express a wish about a past event that did not occur. It follows the pattern of "I wish..." + past perfect tense (had + past participle) to convey a hypothetical situation in the past.

A) Political and economic uncertainty rises in times of global crisis.

This question tests understanding of subject-verb agreement, singular vs. plural nouns, and correct verb tenses, making it challenging for exam-takers.

> 2018\-09\-02 18:20:33 \[scrapy.core.engine] DEBUG: Crawled (400\) https://fbschedules.com/wp\-admin/admin\-ajax.php\> (referer: None) 
> 
> 
> 2018\-09\-02 18:20:33 \[scrapy.spidermiddlewares.httperror] INFO:
>  Ignoring response \<400
>  [https://fbschedules.com/wp\-admin/admin\-ajax.php](https://fbschedules.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php)\>: HTTP status code is
>  not handled or not allowed 
> 
> 
> 2018\-09\-02 18:20:33 \[scrapy.core.engine] INFO: Closing spider
>  (finished)

\#\#\# Top Answer: I had the same issue, 
I handled it by adding meta argument to the `FormRequest` parameters.

Try using `scrapy.FormRequest` instead of `scrapy.FormRequest.from_response` :

```
meta = {'handle_httpstatus_all': True}
yield FormRequest('https://fbschedules.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php',
                                           headers=headers,
                                           formdata=data,
                                           method='POST',
                                           meta=meta,
                                           callback=self.schedule_parse)

```

21.answer:
Here's a multi-form exam question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: When attempting to scrape a website that uses AJAX requests, a developer encounters a 400 response error using Scrapy. Which of the following modifications to the Scrapy FormRequest is most likely to resolve this issue and allow successful scraping of the AJAX content?

A) Change the request method from POST to GET
B) Remove the 'X-Requested-With': 'XMLHttpRequest' header
C) Add meta={'handle_httpstatus_all': True} to the FormRequest parameters
D) Replace FormRequest.from_response with Request.get

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
The correct answer is C. Adding meta={'handle_httpstatus_all': True} to the FormRequest parameters allows Scrapy to handle all HTTP status codes, including 400 errors. This modification enables the spider to process the response even if it receives a 400 status code, which is likely the cause of the initial scraping failure.

Option A is incorrect because changing the method to GET would not match the original AJAX request, which uses POST.

Option B is incorrect because removing the 'X-Requested-With' header might actually make the request less like a genuine AJAX request, potentially causing more issues.

Option D is incorrect because using Request.get would change the request method to GET and wouldn't include the necessary form data for the AJAX request.

The key to solving this issue is to allow Scrapy to handle all HTTP status codes, which is achieved by adding the meta parameter as suggested in option C.

\#\#\# User: **Statistics.com published a problem of the week:**
The rate of residential insurance fraud is 10% (one out of ten claims is fraudulent). A consultant has proposed a machine learning system to review claims and classify them as fraud or no\-fraud. The system is 90% effective in detecting the fraudulent claims, but only 80% effective in correctly classifying the non\-fraud claims (it mistakenly labels one in five as “fraud”). If the system classifies a claim as fraudulent, what is the probability that it really is fraudulent?

[https://www.statistics.com/news/231/192/Conditional\-Probability/?showtemplate\=true](https://www.statistics.com/news/231/192/Conditional-Probability/?showtemplate=true)

My peer and I both came up with the same answer independently and it doesn't match the published solution.

Our solution:

> (.9\*.1\)/((.9\*.1\)\+(.2\*.9\))\=1/3

Their solution:

> This is a problem in conditional probability. (It’s also a Bayesian problem, but applying the formula in Bayes Rule only helps to obscure what’s going on.) Consider 100 claims. 10 will be fraudulent, and the system will correctly label 9 of them as “fraud.” 90 claims will be OK, but the system will incorrectly classify 72 (80%) as “fraud.” So a total of 81 claims have been labeled as fraudulent, but only 9 of them, 11%, are actually fraudulent.

Who was right

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I believe that you and your colleague are correct. Statistics.com has the correct line of thinking, but makes a simple mistake. Out of the 90 "OK" claims, we expect 20% of them to be incorrectly classified as fraud, not 80%. 20% of 90 is 18, leading to 9 correctly identified claims and 18 incorrect claims, with a ratio of 1/3, exactly what Bayes' rule yields.

24.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the scenario:

Question: A company receives 1000 insurance claims. The true fraud rate is 10%, and a new AI system has been implemented to detect fraud. The system correctly identifies 90% of fraudulent claims and 80% of non-fraudulent claims. If the system flags a claim as fraudulent, what is the probability that the claim is actually fraudulent?

A) 1/3
B) 11%
C) 31%
D) 2/7

Correct Answer: A

Explanation:
A) 1/3 is correct. Using Bayes' theorem:
P(Fraud|Flagged) = P(Flagged|Fraud) * P(Fraud) / [P(Flagged|Fraud) * P(Fraud) + P(Flagged|Not Fraud) * P(Not Fraud)]
= (0.9 * 0.1) / [(0.9 * 0.1) + (0.2 * 0.9)] = 1/3

B) 11% is incorrect. This was the mistaken result in the original problem, which incorrectly applied the false positive rate.

C) 31% is incorrect. This might result from misapplying the given percentages without using Bayes' theorem.

D) 2/7 is incorrect. This is close to the correct answer but slightly off, possibly due to a calculation error.

To verify:
Out of 1000 claims, 100 are fraudulent and 900 are not.
90 fraudulent claims are correctly flagged (90% of 100).
180 non-fraudulent claims are incorrectly flagged (20% of 900).
Total flagged: 90 + 180 = 270
Probability of fraud given flag: 90/270 = 1/3

This question tests understanding of conditional probability, Bayes' theorem, and careful analysis of given information.

\#\#\# User: I am working with two highly skewed Bernoulli distributions where 96\-99\+% of the samples are in the "false" category, and the rest are in the "true" category (sort of speak). I am looking for a two\-sided test of difference of proportions between the two samples. I can often achieve 500\+ "trues" and tens or hundreds of thousands of "falses" in a reasonable time but I'm not sure if approximation to the normal distribution can withstand this extreme skewness.

I initially thought I might need something non\-parametric, but here, I actually know the distribution.

I have been using a student's t\-test, while paying attention to sample size estimation, but past experience has led me to be skeptical of its results. Thanks for your help.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: One common rule of thumb is that you can safely use the normal approximation when comparing two proportions as long as there are at least 10 "Trues" and 10 "Falses" in each group, if you have 500\+ trues in each group then that is greater than 10 and using the normal approximation is still reasonable. You can convince yourself of this by simulating several datasets with the sample sizes and proportions that you have, then computing the test statistic for the normal approximation (simulate under the null of equal proportions), then plot a histogram of all these simulated test statistics. If this histogram is approximately normal then a normal approximation is fine.

You could also use Fisher's exact test (probably use sampling to get the estimated p\-value, your sample size will require quite a bit of time to compute the exact p\-value from this test).

Here's a multi-form question based on the given limit problem:

Question: Consider the limit $$\lim_{x\to0}\frac{\tan6x}{\sin3x}$$
Which of the following statements is correct?

A) The limit can be evaluated by directly substituting x = 0, resulting in 2.

B) The limit does not exist because the denominator approaches 0 faster than the numerator.

C) The limit equals 2, and can be found by using the identity $\tan6x = \frac{2\tan3x}{1-\tan^23x}$.

D) The limit equals 2, and can be found by rewriting the expression as $2\frac{\cos(3x)}{\cos(6x)}$ and then evaluating as x approaches 0.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because direct substitution leads to 0/0, which is indeterminate.
B is incorrect; the limit does exist.
C uses a correct identity but is unnecessarily complicated and doesn't lead directly to the answer.
D is correct. By rewriting $\tan6x$ as $\frac{\sin6x}{\cos6x}$, then using the double angle formula for sine, we get $2\frac{\cos(3x)}{\cos(6x)}$. As x approaches 0, both cosine terms approach 1, leaving us with 2 as the limit.

\#\#\# User: I have a set of points (meteorological stations) with 5km buffers around them. Additionally, I have a set of polygons (municipalities) in which those stations are located.

I would like to have data on how much of the buffer is filled by each polygon but I was not able to find a function or a way to do it. So for example for point A I would have that in the buffer of 5km there is 80% of polygon B and 20% of polygon C as the output.

Edit: 
The anwsers provided do anwser this question in a setting in which I know what polygons and buffers I need to have in the code or when I can do it manualy. Problem is that in my setting with 1 shapefile having 500 polygons and one vector layer having 13000 buffers I am unable to do this manually and I am asking if there is an easier way to do it. I tried implementing the approaches in the questions but I was unable to use them on my example in big scale. Moreover I had problems with coding that I also noted in comments down below. 

Main difference to the other similar question provided is that I have 2 vector layers (Buffer with 500 buffers and Municipalities a shape file with 500 different polygons). Previous questions were analyzing this question in situations in which I know precisely the polygons and buffers analyzed, at least that is how I understood them, so after trying to use those approaches on my datasets I was not able to replicate them.

Another way of approaching this problem for me is to use join attributes by location \-one\-to\-many and then getting averages of the duplicate results, only problem is that then I take average of polygons instead of their weights corresponding to % of intersection with the buffer. In my case I do not know what polygons of the shapefile are going to intersect what buffers, or even if the buffer is going to be intersected by 1,2 or more polygons

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You can achieve this using the **DB Manager** of QGIS.

You choose **Database / Database Manager / Database Manager** then **Virtual Layers / Qgis Layers** you can then try the following query :

```
select buf.id, mun.name, st_area(st_intersection(buf.geometry, mun.geometry))/st_area(buf.geometry)
from buffer_layer buf, municipalities_layer mun
where st_intersects(buf.geometry, mun.geometry)
order by buf.id

```

I assume your buffer table has an '**id**' attribute and your municipalities layer a '**name**' attribute.

You can then load the result in the layer manager.

\#\#\# User: What is more fuel efficient: Two identical cars running at 50mph or one being tied to the other and only the first dragging both at 50mph? Or what requires less fuel: Two cars to start from stop and achieve 50mph or the same cars tied one after the other and only the first dragging them from stop up to 50mph? If you can calculate how much in percentage the difference in fuel consumption would be (if any) it would be highly appreciated.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It is not that easy. Now one engine is delivering about twice as much torque and was probably not designed for that. An engine specifically designed to deliver more torque would like be more efficient than the two combined.

Lets look torque alone. Ignore the tow rope and assume the second is far enough back to not get any draft. In this case wind resistance is the same \- shape, size, and speed of the car is the same. Rolling resistance would most likely be more in the tow. Rolling resistance goes up with torque and has a sweet spot. Years ago motor trend was testing an Audi Quatro and to the test the resistance of the front transfer box they disconnected the drive shaft and got a lower top speed. Then they switched around and only drove with with rear and again got a lower top speed. After much analysis they discovered all 4 wheel sharing the torque had the lowest rolling resistance.

I have ArcGIS 10\.1 sp1 installed on my computer. 

I have followed these steps so far:

2. changed values 10\.0 to 10\.1 in files agent\_analyst.bat and agent\_analyst\_run.bat in agent analyst installation folder
3\- added the ArcGIS 10\.1 installation path "for example C:\\Program Files (x86\)\\ArcGIS\\Desktop10\.1" to environment variables ARC\_JAVA \& ARC\_JAVAW \& ARCOBJECTS\_JAR ([Which GIS software or plugins can perform a Cellular Automata Simulation?](https://gis.stackexchange.com/questions/44285/which-gis-software-or-plugins-can-perform-a-cellular-automata-simulation/44291#44291))

I restarted and still have had no luck (just a black box flashes up when I create a new agent analyst tool or try to edit the tool). 

Is there some other step I need to do or have I done one of the above steps incorrectly? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I also got Agent Analyst to work with ArcGIS 10\.2 (at least so far). I had to perform the steps noted above, but given that it was a bit confusing with some of the responses I will summarize here:

1. Create **Refresh.exe.config** file with a text editor and save it along with **Refresh.exe** (typically in **C:\\Repast 3\\Agent Analyst\\Refresh**). The **Refresh.exe.config** contents will be identical to the contents of the configuration file described here ("Update 2"): [ArcGIS 10\.1 using Repast's Agent Analyst Extension \- refresh.exe does not work](https://gis.stackexchange.com/questions/48655/arcgis-10-1-using-repasts-agent-analyst-extension-refresh-exe-does-not-work) but you must replace newVersion\="10\.1\.0\.0" with newVersion\="10\.2\.0\.0".
2. As noted above, edit the **agent\_analyst.bat** and **agent\_analyst\_run.bat** files in the installation folder (**C:\\Repast 3\\Agent Analyst**) so that the folder paths contain Desktop10\.2 in the folder path strings: 

```
rem set ARC_JAVA="C:\Program Files (x86)\ArcGIS\Desktop10.2\java\jre\bin\java"
rem set ARC_JAVAW="C:\Program Files (x86)\ArcGIS\Desktop10.2\java\jre\bin\javaw"
rem set ARCOBJECTS_JAR="C:\Program Files (x86)\ArcGIS\Desktop10.2\java\lib\arcobjects.jar"

```
3. Then, edit your Environment Variables to make sure that ARC\_JAVA, ARC\_JAVAW, and ARCOBJECTS\_JAR have a fully specified path entered for each variable (like what is in the .bat files above).
4. Then, in my Environment Variables, I had to move ARC\_JAVA (**C:\\Program Files (x86\)\\ArcGIS\\Desktop10\.2\\java\\jre\\bin\\java**), ARC\_JAVAW (**C:\\Program Files (x86\)\\ArcGIS\\Desktop10\.2\\java\\jre\\bin\\javaw**), ARCOBJECTS\_JAR (**C:\\Program Files (x86\)\\ArcGIS\\Desktop10\.2\\java\\lib\\arcobjects.jar**), AGENT\_ANALYST (**C:\\Repast 3\\Agent Analyst**), and AGENT\_ANALYST\_VOL (**C:**) from my User Variables to my System Variables. Depending on your situation, I foresee that some people may not need to do this. If you install software and manage your system with a separate ADMIN account, then I think you will need to do this...I had to do so to get it to work.
5. Finally, make sure you restart your system and open a fresh ArcGIS session...

I'm new to Agent Analyst so I don't know if there will be other issues down the road, but now I am at least able to see the Agent Analyst user interface when adding a new tool so it appears that everything is working well so far.

If I am looking for something specific, I post very specific requirements. I get answers from people who seem to just Googled the question and did a copy of paste. Their solution is far from satisfying the requirements.
Example: I need a network sniffer that does this and this and this and this. I get a flood of 'WireShark' recommendations just because its a popular product. Do they ACTUALLY know it satisfies my requirements. NO. They mention it just because they HEARD its good.

2\- I get an answer. It gets one upvote. I leave a comment indicating it actually doesn't answer the question and I leave a reason. You would think people read the comment. No. The answer gets a lot of subsequent upvotes!! Upvoting for the sake of upvoting and getting points. Then the question doesn't get anymore answers. I guess users think if an answer has many upvotes, it must be the right answer? No it didn't and I mention this. and then the question loses steam and no one bothers offering more help. Frustrating.

([similar question](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/22024/problems-with-stack-overflows-reputation-point-system)) 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 1. Yep. Bad answers happen. Writing *really* clear and concise questions helps but does not prevent them.
2. Good ole pile on. This happens too. Again really clear questions will help, as will clear, fast comments, and downvotes.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In a Magento 2 project, you need to modify the product tabs on the product item page to make all tabs collapsed by default on mobile view, while keeping them expanded on desktop. Which of the following approaches correctly implements this functionality?

A) Create a custom JavaScript file and use CSS media queries to toggle the tab states based on screen size.

B) Override the core details.phtml file in your theme, remove the existing data-mage-init attribute, and add a script that uses matchMedia to control tab behavior based on viewport width.

C) Modify the core Magento_Catalog module directly to implement conditional tab behavior based on user agent detection.

D) Use Magento's layout XML to add a custom block that overrides the default tab behavior only on mobile devices.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
Option B is the correct approach as it follows the best practices for customizing Magento 2 functionality:

1. It involves creating a copy of the core details file in the local theme, which is the recommended way to override core templates.
2. It removes the existing data-mage-init attribute, which allows for custom initialization of the tabs.
3. It adds a script that uses matchMedia to detect viewport size and apply different tab configurations for desktop and mobile views.
4. The script uses the accordion widget for mobile view, ensuring all tabs are collapsed by default (active: false).
5. For desktop view, it sets collapsible to false, maintaining the default expanded state.

Option A is incorrect because while it could potentially work, it's not the Magento-recommended approach and may not integrate well with other Magento features.

Option C is incorrect and should be avoided, as directly modifying core modules is considered bad practice and can lead to issues with future updates.

Option D is incorrect because while layout XML is powerful, it's not the appropriate tool for implementing this specific JavaScript-based functionality.

\#\#\# User: When we tried to edit/add products, we are getting following error in magento

Source model "temando/entity\_attribute\_source\_packaging\_mode" not found for attribute 

"temando\_packaging\_mode"

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Remove the README.md from your root Magento folder. There is only one README.md in the Magento Connect package and it located in the root folder.
You will need FTP/SSH access to perform this, but simply removing that file should fix this issue for you.
If you continue having that error but with another file after removing the README, you will have to remove them all manually the same way you removed the README.md

35.answer:

Question: A Magento e-commerce site is experiencing an error when attempting to edit or add products. The error message states: "Source model 'temando/entity_attribute_source_packaging_mode' not found for attribute 'temando_packaging_mode'". What is the most likely cause of this issue and its solution?

A) The database is corrupted and needs to be restored from a backup.
B) The Magento core files are outdated and require a full system update.
C) There is a README.md file in the root Magento folder that needs to be removed.
D) The server's PHP version is incompatible with the current Magento installation.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The issue is likely caused by the presence of a README.md file in the root Magento folder. This file is typically included in Magento Connect packages but should not be present in the root directory of a live installation. Removing this file via FTP or SSH access should resolve the error. If similar errors persist with other files, they may also need to be removed manually. This solution addresses the specific error message mentioned and aligns with the troubleshooting steps provided in the StackExchange documentation.

\#\#\# User: I installed the VMware bundle on my Ubuntu 11\.04 successfully but when I open it it gives me this window 

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/tpJeH.png)

and I don't know the path to this C headers.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
```
cd /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/build/include/linux
sudo ln -s ../generated/utsrelease.h
sudo ln -s ../generated/autoconf.h
sudo ln -s ../generated/uapi/linux/version.h 

```

After adding the symlink, the path is `/usr/src/linux-headers-$(uname -r)/include` (Thanks @Kariem!)

36.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: You are troubleshooting a VMware installation on Ubuntu 11.04 that fails due to missing C headers. Which sequence of commands would correctly create the necessary symlinks and provide the proper path for the C headers?

A) 
```
cd /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/build/include/linux
sudo ln -s ../generated/utsrelease.h
sudo ln -s ../generated/autoconf.h
sudo ln -s ../generated/uapi/linux/version.h
Path: /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/build/include
```

B) 
```
cd /usr/src/linux-headers-$(uname -r)/include/linux
sudo ln -s ../generated/utsrelease.h
sudo ln -s ../generated/autoconf.h
sudo ln -s ../generated/uapi/linux/version.h
Path: /usr/src/linux-headers-$(uname -r)/include
```

C) 
```
cd /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/build/include/linux
sudo ln -s ../generated/utsrelease.h
sudo ln -s ../generated/autoconf.h
sudo ln -s ../generated/uapi/linux/version.h
Path: /usr/src/linux-headers-$(uname -r)/include
```

D) 
```
cd /usr/src/linux-headers-$(uname -r)/include/linux
sudo ln -s ../generated/utsrelease.h
sudo ln -s ../generated/autoconf.h
sudo ln -s ../generated/uapi/linux/version.h
Path: /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/build/include
```

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct sequence of commands is provided in option C. It creates the necessary symlinks in the correct directory (/lib/modules/$(uname -r)/build/include/linux) as shown in the original answer. However, the path where VMware should look for the C headers is /usr/src/linux-headers-$(uname -r)/include, as mentioned in the additional note. This combination of creating symlinks in one location but providing a different path for VMware to find the headers is the key to solving the issue.

\#\#\# User: I'd like to receive/record audio from bluetooth device on my linux box. The one I have works properly as a headset (microphone works properly in particular) i.e. on macOS yet I cannot get it working with linux \- raspbian jessy in particular \- yet from what I can see it affects other distros as well. 

* the device is paired and connected properly using `bluetoothctl`
* A2DP profile works correctly
* `pactl ls` reports among others `headset_head_unit: Headset Head Unit (HSP/HFP) (priority 20, available: no)`
* while trying to switch to `headset_head_unit` pulseaudio reports `[pulseaudio] module-bluez5-device.c: Refused to switch profile to headset_head_unit: Not connected`

I've found and tried various suggestions as for upgrading `bluez`, `pulseaudio`, use `ofono` etc. yet without any success. Most common comments are that HSP/HFP support has been dropped in recent `bluez` and the `ofono` should be used (yet I'm not sure how ofono is supposed to help here as AFAIK it is related when BT susystem is being used as a client i.e. connected to mobile phone). I can see a number of unresolved bugs i.e. for freedesktop [here](https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=73325) and [here](https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=93898), [redhat](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1311238), [ubuntu](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/bluez/+bug/1438510) and [debian](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=757731) and also similar questions asked on stackexchange. 
While there are some successes reported, I was not able to move forward trying i.e. 

* use `pulseaudio` config `load-module module-bluetooth-discover headset=ofono` (and `auto`, `native` variants as well), versions 7, 8, 10
* `bluez` 5\.24, 5\.42, 5\.43 (was not able to found other versions for debian as i.e. there is some success reported with `bluez` 5\.35\)
* re\-pairing and reconnecting the headset device with `bluetoothctl`

Also there is some confusion in the reports as probably some people are mixing using linux bluetooth stack as client/server \- at least this is my understanding of using `ofono`. 

While there are also some problem reports regarding bluetooth on RPI 3 in particular, I would like to find first any sign if the HFP/HSP is ever possible with current `bluez`/`pulseaudio`. Having any success report with clear steps i.e. on debian (and even better on raspbian) would help me a lot. Even any successful setup on any other distro may help me to build the same on my box. Looks like the problem affects `pulseaudio`/`bluez` stack for more then a year and it is hard to believe people cannot use their BT headsets i.e. for VOiP calls for so long... Not sure if I've provided all the important details from my investigation so in case of comments I can update this question.

Also wonder if there is some bug report with some active development and chances for solution.

**UPDATE:**
Most probably after removing `ofono` I've finally managed to be able to switch the connection to `headset_head_unit` yet while trying to record or play sound the device shows some activity (i.e. pulsating builtin led) but no data is being received/send (i.e. `parec` creates empty `wav` of size 44b which is just wav header). I've tested same device using `a2dp_sink` profile and can play sound without any problem. I wonder how it can be debugged.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: ### My solution:

I just found my solution in Fedora 26, using Plantronics Legend and Pluggable Bluetooth USB, after a lot of searching.

I am going back through my history, and updating threads with my solution where I can. This worked for me, direct from Plugable (which is the USB module I am using).

See [this](https://plugable.com/2014/06/23/plugable-usb-bluetooth-adapter-solving-hfphsp-profile-issues-on-linux/) post.

### Command summary per above link

```
wget https://s3.amazonaws.com/plugable/bin/fw-0a5c_21e8.hcd
sudo mkdir /lib/firmware/brcm
sudo mv fw-0a5c_21e8.hcd /lib/firmware/brcm/BCM20702A0-0a5c-21e8.hcd
sudo cp /lib/firmware/brcm/BCM20702A0-0a5c-21e8.hcd /lib/firmware/brcm/BCM20702A1-0a5c-21e8.hcd

```

Then reboot.

\#\#\# User: I am putting new carpet down and want to run my rear 5\.1 speaker wire under the carpet. I know that I will want to replace it once a year (I am weird like that), so I thought I'd get a few of these:

[Corduct 15 ft Cord Protector](http://www.homedepot.com/h_d1/N-5yc1v/R-100164060/h_d2/ProductDisplay?langId=-1&storeId=10051&catalogId=10053)

The idea is that I could keep the wire as short as possible. It should be easy to replace the wire, too. My idea is to take some very long string, tie something metalic to it that will fit through the channel in the cord protector, then take a magnet to the metal object and drag the string through to the other side. I would then tie my speaker wire to the end of the string and pull it through.

Does this sound like a workable approach? The above\-linked cord protector looks reasonably thin, so I don't think it'd be too noticeable if stepped on through the new thick padding and thick carpet I will soon be getting.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You'll end up with two lumps in the carpet that can't be easily removed. You'll also have holes in your carpet at each side for the wire. So unless you're going for the college dorm look, I'd recommend against this. If you do it anyway, the only way to get the wire through this is to attach it to the existing wire and use that to pull it through. I doubt the magnet idea would ever work, and trying to push the wire through would just fold on itself since it's not rigid enough.

As for the way I would do it, the easy way is to pick up a box of [nail clips](http://www.homedepot.com/h_d1/N-5yc1v/R-202698897/h_d2/ProductDisplay?langId=-1&storeId=10051&catalogId=10053) and tack the wire down around the baseboard. With these, you can pull the nail slightly and spin the clip 180 degrees to easily add or remove a wire behind it. After enough time and especially enough furniture, you tend to forget they are even there. You can also have a nicer look with some [wall mounted conduit](http://www.homedepot.com/h_d1/N-5yc1v/R-202562905/h_d2/ProductDisplay?langId=-1&storeId=10051&catalogId=10053).

The excessive option is to open up the floor or below ceiling and run [flexible conduit](http://www.homedepot.com/h_d1/N-5yc1v/R-202316470/h_d2/ProductDisplay?langId=-1&storeId=10051&catalogId=10053&superSkuId=202891061) through the floor, preferably with the ends in the wall behind [a modular plate](http://www.homedepot.com/h_d1/N-5yc1v/R-100356860/h_d2/ProductDisplay?langId=-1&storeId=10051&catalogId=10053) with the appropriate [connectors](http://www.homedepot.com/h_d1/N-5yc1v/R-100356844/h_d2/ProductDisplay?langId=-1&storeId=10051&catalogId=10053) installed. If you happen to already have a wall and/or ceiling exposed, running conduit would be a great idea, I only consider it excessive if you're pulling down an existing wall to install it.

38.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: An audiophile wants to install rear 5.1 speaker wires under new carpet and plans to replace them annually. Which of the following approaches is MOST recommended for this scenario, considering both practicality and aesthetics?

A) Use a cord protector under the carpet and employ a magnet-and-string method to thread new wires through annually.

B) Install nail clips around the baseboard to secure the speaker wires, allowing for easy replacement.

C) Open up the floor to run flexible conduit with modular wall plates and connectors at each end.

D) Use wall-mounted conduit along the baseboards to house the speaker wires.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
A) This approach is not recommended as it would create noticeable lumps in the carpet and leave holes at entry/exit points. The magnet-and-string method is also unlikely to work effectively.

B) This is the most practical and aesthetically pleasing solution for the given scenario. Nail clips allow for easy wire replacement without damaging walls or carpet, and become unnoticeable over time, especially with furniture placement.

C) While this provides a professional solution, it's considered excessive for the situation, especially if it requires opening up existing walls or floors solely for this purpose.

D) Wall-mounted conduit is a viable option but may be more visually obvious than nail clips and doesn't offer as much flexibility for annual wire replacement.

The nail clip method (B) offers the best balance of practicality, aesthetics, and ease of wire replacement for the described scenario.
